In Geological History, we standardize on the Geological Time Scale.

The definition of standardized international units of GTS is the responsibility of the International Commission on Stratigraphy (ICS), a constituent body of the International Union of Geological Sciences (IUGS). Their primary objective is to precisely define global chronostratigraphic units of the International Chronostratigraphic Chart (ICC), which are in turn used to define geochronological units.
# The Geological Time Scale
The GTS is divided into chronostratigraphic units and their corresponding geochronologic units.

> [!NOTE]
> - **Chronostraigraphy** is a part of **stratigraphy**. **Stratigraphy** is the branch of geology concerned with the study of rock layers (strata) and layering (stratification).
> - Chronostratigraphy is one of the three subdivisions of stratigraphy (the other two being lithostratigraphy and biostratigraphy), dealing with placing an absolute age to rock strata. By placing absolute ages on rock strata, we are able to relate them to their relative formation in time, and hence assign geochronological time periods to them.
> - A **chronostratigraphic unit** is a body of rock, layered or unlayered, that is defined between stratigraphic horizons which represent specified intervals of geologic time. They include all rocks representative of a specific interval of geologic time.
> - **Geochronology** is the branch of geology that aims to determine the age of rocks, fossils and sediments either through absolute or relative means.
> - A **geochronological unit** is a subdivision of geologic time.

In simple terms, chronostratigraphy deals with the dating of physical evidence, and geochronology deals with forming the temporal evidence extrapolated from it. In other words, chronostatigraphic units define a rock's identity according to age, while geochronographic units define the time period in which the rock was formed.

Much like saying "Egyptian Civilization" formed in "3 Millenia BC".

> [!NOTE] How chronostratigraphic units are separated, and hence geochronometric units are defined
> A **Global Boundary Stratotype Section and Point (GSSP)** is an internationally agreed upon reference point on a stratigraphic section which defines the lower boundaries of stages on the geologic time scale. (Recently this has been used to define the base of a system)
> 
> A **Global Standard Stratigraphic Age (GSSA)** is a numeric only, chronologic reference point used to define the base of geochronologic units prior to the Cryogenian. These points are arbitrarily defined. They are used where GSSPs have not yet been established. Research is ongoing to define GSSPs for the base of all units that are currently defined by GSSAs. 

The units used in GTS are as follows:

| Chronostratigraphic Units (Strata Type) | Geochronometric Units (Time) | Time Span                                                   |
| --------------------------------------- | ---------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------- |
| Eonothem                                | Eon                          | Several hundred million years to two billion years          |
| Erathem                                 | Era                          | Tens to hundreds of millions of years                       |
| System                                  | Period                       | Millions of years to tens of millions of years              |
| Series                                  | Epoch                        | Hundreds of thousands of years to tens of millions of years |
| Subseries                               | Subepoch                     | Thousands of years to millions of years                     |
| Stage                                   | Age                          | Thousands of years to millions of years                     |

                  | [Upper/Late](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Cretaceous "Late Cretaceous")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   | [Maastrichtian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maastrichtian "Maastrichtian")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               | [Flowering plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") proliferate (after developing many features since the Carboniferous), along with new types of [insects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insect "Insect"), while other seed plants (gymnosperms and seed ferns) decline. More modern [teleost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleost "Teleost") fish begin to appear. [Ammonoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonoids "Ammonoids"), [belemnites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belemnoidea "Belemnoidea"), [rudist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudist "Rudist") [bivalves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bivalve "Bivalve"), [sea urchins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_urchins "Sea urchins") and [sponges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sponges "Sponges") all common. Many new types of [dinosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinosaur "Dinosaur") (e.g. [tyrannosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrannosauridae "Tyrannosauridae"), [titanosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Titanosauridae "Titanosauridae"), [hadrosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadrosauridae "Hadrosauridae"), and [ceratopsids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceratopsidae "Ceratopsidae")) evolve on land, while [crocodilians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocodilia "Crocodilia") appear in water and probably cause the last temnospondyls to die out; and [mosasaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosasaur "Mosasaur") and modern types of sharks appear in the sea. The revolution started by marine reptiles and sharks reaches its peak, though ichthyosaurs vanish few million years after being heavily reduced at the [Bonarelli Event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonarelli_Event "Bonarelli Event"). Toothed and [toothless avian birds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neornithes "Neornithes") coexist with pterosaurs. Modern [monotremes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotremes "Monotremes"), [metatherian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metatheria "Metatheria") (including [marsupials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marsupials "Marsupials"), who migrate to South America) and [eutherian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eutheria "Eutheria") (including [placentals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placentals "Placentals"), [leptictidans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leptictida "Leptictida") and [cimolestans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimolesta "Cimolesta")) mammals appear while the last non-mammalian cynodonts die out. First [terrestrial crabs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrestrial_crabs "Terrestrial crabs"). Many snails become terrestrial. Further breakup of Gondwana creates [South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_America "South America"), [Afro-](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Africa "Africa")[Arabia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Asia "West Asia"), [Antarctica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctica "Antarctica"), [Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceania "Oceania"), [Madagascar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madagascar "Madagascar"), [Greater India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent"), and the [South Atlantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Atlantic "South Atlantic"), [Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") and [Antarctic Oceans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antarctic_Ocean "Antarctic Ocean") and the islands of the Indian (and some of the Atlantic) Ocean. Beginning of [Laramide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laramide_Orogeny "Laramide Orogeny") and [Sevier Orogenies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sevier_Orogeny "Sevier Orogeny") of the [Rocky Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"). [Atmospheric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth "Atmosphere of Earth") oxygen and carbon dioxide levels similar to present day. [Acritarchs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acritarch "Acritarch") disappear. Climate initially warm, but later it cools.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       |

                                                                                                         | Climate becomes humid again. [Gymnosperms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gymnosperm "Gymnosperm") (especially [conifers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conifer "Conifer"), [cycads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycad "Cycad") and [cycadeoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cycadeoids "Cycadeoids")) and [ferns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fern "Fern") common. [Dinosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinosaur "Dinosaur"), including [sauropods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauropod "Sauropod"), [carnosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnosaur "Carnosaur"), [stegosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stegosaur "Stegosaur") and [coelurosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coelurosaur "Coelurosaur"), become the dominant land vertebrates. Mammals diversify into [shuotheriids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shuotheriidae "Shuotheriidae"), [australosphenidans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australosphenida "Australosphenida"), [eutriconodonts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eutriconodonts "Eutriconodonts"), [multituberculates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multituberculates "Multituberculates"), [symmetrodonts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetrodonts "Symmetrodonts"), [dryolestids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dryolestids "Dryolestids") and [boreosphenidans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boreosphenida "Boreosphenida") but mostly remain small. First [birds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avialae "Avialae"), [lizards, snakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squamata "Squamata") and [turtles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turtles "Turtles"). First [brown algae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_algae "Brown algae"), [rays](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batoidea "Batoidea"), [shrimps](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shrimps "Shrimps"), [crabs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crabs "Crabs") and [lobsters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lobsters "Lobsters"). [Parvipelvian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvipelvia "Parvipelvia") ichthyosaurs and [plesiosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plesiosaur "Plesiosaur") diverse. Rhynchocephalians throughout the world. [Bivalves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bivalve "Bivalve"), [ammonoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonoid "Ammonoid") and [belemnites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belemnoidea "Belemnoidea") abundant. [Sea urchins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_urchin "Sea urchin") very common, along with [crinoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crinoid "Crinoid"), [starfish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starfish "Starfish"), [sponges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porifera "Porifera"), and [terebratulid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terebratulida "Terebratulida") and [rhynchonellid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhynchonellida "Rhynchonellida") [brachiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachiopod "Brachiopod"). Breakup of [Pangaea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pangaea "Pangaea") into [Laurasia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurasia "Laurasia") and [Gondwana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gondwana "Gondwana"), with the latter also breaking into two main parts; the [Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific "Pacific") and [Arctic Oceans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean") form. [Tethys Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tethys_Ocean "Tethys Ocean") forms. [Nevadan orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nevadan_orogeny "Nevadan orogeny") in North America. [Rangitata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangitata_Orogeny "Rangitata Orogeny") and [Cimmerian orogenies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimmerian_Orogeny "Cimmerian Orogeny") taper off. Atmospheric CO2 levels 34 times the present-day levels (12001500 ppmv, compared to today's 400 ppmv[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#cite_note-Royer_2006-89)[[note 8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#cite_note-atmospheric-carbon-dioxide-90)). [Crocodylomorphs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocodylomorph "Crocodylomorph") (last pseudosuchians) seek out an aquatic lifestyle. [Mesozoic marine revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesozoic_marine_revolution "Mesozoic marine revolution") continues from late Triassic.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            | [Archosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archosaur "Archosaur") dominant on land as [pseudosuchians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudosuchia "Pseudosuchia") and in the air as [pterosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pterosaur "Pterosaur"). [Dinosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dinosaurs "Dinosaurs") also arise from bipedal archosaurs. [Ichthyosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ichthyosaur "Ichthyosaur") and [nothosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nothosaur "Nothosaur") (a group of sauropterygians) dominate large marine fauna. [Cynodonts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cynodont "Cynodont") become smaller and nocturnal, eventually becoming the first true [mammals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammals "Mammals"), while other remaining synapsids die out. [Rhynchosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhynchosaur "Rhynchosaur") (archosaur relatives) also common. [Seed ferns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_ferns "Seed ferns") called _[Dicroidium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dicroidium "Dicroidium")_ remained common in Gondwana, before being replaced by advanced gymnosperms. Many large aquatic [temnospondyl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temnospondyli "Temnospondyli") amphibians. [Ceratitidan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceratitida "Ceratitida") [ammonoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonoids "Ammonoids") extremely common. [Modern corals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scleractinia "Scleractinia") and [teleost](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teleost "Teleost") fish appear, as do many modern [insect](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insect "Insect") orders and suborders. First [starfish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starfish "Starfish"). [Andean Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andes_Mountains "Andes Mountains") in South America. [Cimmerian Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cimmerian_Orogeny "Cimmerian Orogeny") in Asia. [Rangitata Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rangitata_Orogeny "Rangitata Orogeny") begins in New Zealand. [Hunter-Bowen Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-Bowen_Orogeny "Hunter-Bowen Orogeny") in [Northern Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Australia "Northern Australia"), Queensland and [New South Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales") ends, (c. 260225Ma). [Carnian pluvial event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnian_pluvial_event "Carnian pluvial event") occurs around 234232 Ma, allowing the first dinosaurs and [lepidosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lepidosaurs "Lepidosaurs") (including [rhynchocephalians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhynchocephalia "Rhynchocephalia")) to radiate. [Triassic-Jurassic extinction event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triassic-Jurassic_extinction_event "Triassic-Jurassic extinction event") occurs 201Ma, wiping out all [conodonts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conodonts "Conodonts") and the [last parareptiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procolophonidae "Procolophonidae"), many marine reptiles (e.g. all sauropterygians except [plesiosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plesiosaurs "Plesiosaurs") and all ichthyosaurs except [parvipelvians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvipelvia "Parvipelvia")), all [crocopodans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocopoda "Crocopoda") except crocodylomorphs, pterosaurs, and dinosaurs, and many ammonoids (including the whole [Ceratitida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceratitida "Ceratitida")), bivalves, brachiopods, corals and sponges. [supercontinent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercontinent "Supercontinent") [Pangaea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pangaea "Pangaea"), creating the [Urals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urals "Urals"), [Ouachitas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouachitas "Ouachitas") and [Appalachians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains"), among other mountain ranges (the superocean [Panthalassa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panthalassa "Panthalassa") or Proto-Pacific also forms). End of Permo-Carboniferous glaciation. Hot and dry climate. A possible drop in oxygen levels. [Synapsids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synapsida "Synapsida") ([pelycosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pelycosaur "Pelycosaur") and [therapsids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Therapsid "Therapsid")) become widespread and dominant, while [parareptiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parareptile "Parareptile") and [temnospondyl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temnospondyli "Temnospondyli") [amphibians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian") remain common, with the latter probably giving rise to [modern amphibians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lissamphibia "Lissamphibia") in this period. In the mid-Permian, lycophytes are heavily replaced by ferns and seed plants. [Beetles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beetles "Beetles") and [flies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fly "Fly") evolve. The very large arthropods and non-tetrapod tetrapodomorphs go extinct. Marine life flourishes in warm shallow reefs; [productid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Productida "Productida") and [spiriferid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiriferida "Spiriferida") brachiopods, bivalves, [forams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foram "Foram"), ammonoids (including goniatites), and [orthoceridans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthocerida "Orthocerida") all abundant. [Crown reptiles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauria "Sauria") arise from earlier diapsids, and split into the ancestors of [lepidosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lepidosauromorpha "Lepidosauromorpha"), [kuehneosaurids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuehneosauridae "Kuehneosauridae"), [choristoderes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choristodera "Choristodera"), [archosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocopoda "Crocopoda"), [testudinatans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Testudinata "Testudinata"), [ichthyosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ichthyosauromorpha "Ichthyosauromorpha"), [thalattosaurs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thalattosaurs "Thalattosaurs"), and [sauropterygians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sauropterygia "Sauropterygia"). Cynodonts evolve from larger therapsids. [Olson's Extinction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olson%27s_Extinction "Olson's Extinction") (273 Ma), [End-Capitanian extinction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitanian_mass_extinction_event "Capitanian mass extinction event") (260 Ma), and [Permian-Triassic extinction event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permian-Triassic_extinction_event "Permian-Triassic extinction event") (252 Ma) occur one after another: more than 80% of life on Earth becomes extinct in the lattermost, including most [retarian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retaria "Retaria") plankton, corals ([Tabulata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabulata "Tabulata") and [Rugosa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugosa "Rugosa") die out fully), brachiopods, bryozoans, gastropods, ammonoids (the goniatites die off fully), insects, parareptiles, synapsids, amphibians, and crinoids (only [articulates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Articulata_(Crinoidea) "Articulata (Crinoidea)") survived), and all [eurypterids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurypterid "Eurypterid"), [trilobites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trilobite "Trilobite"), [graptolites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graptolite "Graptolite"), [hyoliths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyoliths "Hyoliths"), [edrioasteroid crinozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edrioasteroidea "Edrioasteroidea"), [blastoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blastoid "Blastoid") and [acanthodians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acanthodians "Acanthodians"). [Ouachita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouachita_Orogeny "Ouachita Orogeny") and [Innuitian orogenies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innuitian_orogeny "Innuitian orogeny") in North America. [Uralian orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uralian_orogeny "Uralian orogeny") in Europe/Asia tapers off. [Altaid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altai_Mountains "Altai Mountains") orogeny in Asia. [Hunter-Bowen Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-Bowen_Orogeny "Hunter-Bowen Orogeny") on [Australian continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_(continent) "Australia (continent)") begins (c. 260225Ma), forming the New England Fold Belt. |

earlier [progymnosperms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Progymnosperm "Progymnosperm")), first trees (the progymnosperm _[Archaeopteris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeopteris "Archaeopteris")_), and first [winged insects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pterygota "Pterygota") (palaeoptera and neoptera). [Strophomenid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strophomenida "Strophomenida") and [atrypid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atrypa "Atrypa") [brachiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachiopod "Brachiopod"), [rugose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugosa "Rugosa") and [tabulate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabulata "Tabulata") corals, and [crinoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crinoid "Crinoid") are all abundant in the oceans. First fully coiled cephalopods ([Ammonoidea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonoidea "Ammonoidea") and [Nautilida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nautilida "Nautilida"), independently) with the former group very abundant (especially [goniatites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goniatites "Goniatites")). Trilobites and ostracoderms decline, while jawed fishes ([placoderms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Placodermi "Placodermi"), [lobe-finned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarcopterygii "Sarcopterygii") and [ray-finned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actinopterygii "Actinopterygii") [bony fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osteichthyes "Osteichthyes"), and [acanthodians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acanthodians "Acanthodians") and early [cartilaginous fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chondrichthyes "Chondrichthyes")) proliferate. Some [lobe finned fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrapodomorpha "Tetrapodomorpha") transform into digited [fishapods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stegocephalia "Stegocephalia"), slowly becoming amphibious. The last non-trilobite artiopods die off. First [decapods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decapods "Decapods") (like [prawns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prawns "Prawns")) and [isopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isopods "Isopods"). Pressure from jawed fishes cause eurypterids to decline and [some cephalopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coleoidea "Coleoidea") to lose their shells while anomalocarids vanish. "Old Red Continent" of [Euramerica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euramerica "Euramerica") persists after forming in the Caledonian orogeny. Beginning of [Acadian Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acadian_Orogeny "Acadian Orogeny") for [Anti-Atlas Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlas_Mountains "Atlas Mountains") of North Africa, and [Appalachian Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains") of North America, also the [Antler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antler_Orogeny "Antler Orogeny"), [Variscan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variscan_Orogeny "Variscan Orogeny"), and [Tuhua orogenies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor_Island/Tuhua "Mayor Island/Tuhua") in New Zealand. A series of extinction events, including the massive [Kellwasser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kellwasser_event "Kellwasser event") and [Hangenberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hangenberg_event "Hangenberg event") ones, wipe out many acritarchs, corals, sponges, molluscs, trilobites, eurypterids, graptolites, brachiopods, crinozoans (e.g. all [cystoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cystoids "Cystoids")), and fish, including all placoderms and ostracoderms. First [vascular plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vascular_plant "Vascular plant") and fully terrestrialised arthropods: [myriapods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myriapods "Myriapods"), [hexapods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexapoda "Hexapoda") (including [insects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insects "Insects")), and [arachnids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arachnids "Arachnids"). [Eurypterids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurypterid "Eurypterid") diversify rapidly, becoming widespread and dominant. Cephalopods continue to flourish. True [jawed fishes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawed_fish "Jawed fish"), along with [ostracoderms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ostracoderm "Ostracoderm"), also roam the seas. [Tabulate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabulate_coral "Tabulate coral") and [rugose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugosa "Rugosa") corals, [brachiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachiopod "Brachiopod") (_Pentamerida_, [Rhynchonellida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhynchonellida "Rhynchonellida"), etc.), [cystoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cystoids "Cystoids") and [crinoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crinoid "Crinoid") all abundant. [Trilobites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trilobite "Trilobite") and [molluscs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mollusc "Mollusc") diverse; [graptolites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graptolite "Graptolite") not as varied. Three minor extinction events. Some echinoderms go extinct. Beginning of [Caledonian Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caledonian_Orogeny "Caledonian Orogeny") (collision between Laurentia, Baltica and one of the formerly small Gondwanan terranes) for hills in England, Ireland, Wales, Scotland, and the [Scandinavian Mountains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scandinavian_Mountains "Scandinavian Mountains"). Also continued into Devonian period as the [Acadian Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acadian_Orogeny "Acadian Orogeny"), above (thus Euramerica forms). [Taconic Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taconic_Orogeny "Taconic Orogeny") tapers off. [Icehouse period](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andean-Saharan_glaciation "Andean-Saharan glaciation") ends late in this period after starting in Late Ordovician. [Lachlan Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lachlan_Orogeny "Lachlan Orogeny") on [Australian continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_(continent) "Australia (continent)") tapers off. [Upper/Late](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Ordovician "Late Ordovician")                   | [Hirnantian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hirnantian "Hirnantian")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       | The [Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Ordovician_Biodiversification_Event "Great Ordovician Biodiversification Event") occurs as plankton increase in number: [invertebrates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invertebrate "Invertebrate") diversify into many new types (especially brachiopods and molluscs; e.g. long [straight-shelled](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthoconic "Orthoconic") cephalopods like the long lasting and diverse [Orthocerida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orthocerida "Orthocerida")). Early [corals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coral "Coral"), articulate [brachiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachiopod "Brachiopod") (_Orthida_, _Strophomenida_, etc.), [bivalves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bivalves "Bivalves"), [cephalopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cephalopod "Cephalopod") (nautiloids), [trilobites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trilobite "Trilobite"), [ostracods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ostracod "Ostracod"), [bryozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryozoa "Bryozoa"), many types of [echinoderms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echinoderms "Echinoderms") ([blastoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blastoids "Blastoids"), [cystoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cystoids "Cystoids"), [crinoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crinoids "Crinoids"), [sea urchins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_urchins "Sea urchins"), [sea cucumbers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_cucumbers "Sea cucumbers"), and [star-like forms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asterozoa "Asterozoa"), etc.), branched [graptolites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graptolite "Graptolite"), and other taxa all common. [Acritarchs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acritarch "Acritarch") still persist and common. Cephalopods become dominant and common, with some trending toward a coiled shell. Anomalocarids decline. Mysterious [tentaculitans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tentaculita "Tentaculita") appear. First [eurypterids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurypterids "Eurypterids") and [ostracoderm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ostracoderm "Ostracoderm") fish appear, the latter probably giving rise to the [jawed fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawed_fish "Jawed fish") at the end of the period. First uncontroversial terrestrial [fungi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fungi "Fungi") and fully terrestrialised [plants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embryophytes "Embryophytes"). [Ice age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Ordovician_glaciation "Late Ordovician glaciation") at the end of this period, as well as a series of mass [extinction events](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Late_Ordovician_mass_extinction "Late Ordovician mass extinction"), killing off some cephalopods and many brachiopods, bryozoans, echinoderms, graptolites, trilobites, bivalves, corals and [conodonts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conodonts "Conodonts"). Explosion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambrian_Explosion "Cambrian Explosion") as oxygen levels increase. Numerous fossils; most modern [animal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal "Animal") [phyla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phylum "Phylum") (including [arthropods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthropods "Arthropods"), [molluscs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molluscs "Molluscs"), [annelids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annelids "Annelids"), [echinoderms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echinoderms "Echinoderms"), [hemichordates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemichordates "Hemichordates") and [chordates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chordates "Chordates")) appear. Reef-building [archaeocyathan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeocyatha "Archaeocyatha") sponges initially abundant, then vanish. Stromatolites replace them, but quickly fall prey to the [Agronomic revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agronomic_revolution "Agronomic revolution"), when some animals started burrowing through the microbial mats (affecting some other animals as well). First [artiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artiopods "Artiopods") (including [trilobites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trilobites "Trilobites")), [priapulid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Priapulid "Priapulid") worms, inarticulate [brachiopods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brachiopod "Brachiopod") (unhinged lampshells), [hyoliths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyoliths "Hyoliths"), [bryozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bryozoa "Bryozoa"), [graptolites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graptolites "Graptolites"), pentaradial echinoderms (e.g. [blastozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blastozoa "Blastozoa"), [crinozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crinozoa "Crinozoa") and [eleutherozoans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleutherozoa "Eleutherozoa")), and numerous other animals. [Anomalocarids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomalocarid "Anomalocarid") are dominant and giant predators, while [many Ediacaran fauna die out](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-Ediacaran_extinction "End-Ediacaran extinction"). [Crustaceans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crustacea "Crustacea") and molluscs diversify rapidly. [Prokaryotes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prokaryote "Prokaryote"), [protists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protist "Protist") (e.g., [forams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foram "Foram")), [algae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algae "Algae") and [fungi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fungi "Fungi") continue to present day. First [vertebrates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertebrates "Vertebrates") from earlier chordates. [Petermann Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petermann_Orogeny "Petermann Orogeny") on the [Australian continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_(continent) "Australia (continent)") tapers off (550535Ma). Ross Orogeny in Antarctica. [Delamerian Orogeny](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delamerian_Orogeny "Delamerian Orogeny") (c. 514490 Ma) on [Australian continent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_(continent) "Australia (continent)"). Some small terranes split off from Gondwana. [Atmospheric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere_of_Earth "Atmosphere of Earth") CO2 content roughly 15 times present-day ([Holocene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holocene "Holocene")) levels (6000 ppm compared to today's 400 ppm)[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#cite_note-Royer_2006-89)[[note 8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geologic_time_scale#cite_note-atmospheric-carbon-dioxide-90) [Arthropods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthropods "Arthropods") and [streptophyta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Embryophytes "Embryophytes") start colonising land. 3 extinction events occur 517, 502 & 488 Ma, the [first](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-Botomian_mass_extinction "End-Botomian mass extinction") and [last](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambrian%E2%80%93Ordovician_extinction_event "CambrianOrdovician extinction event") of which wipe out many of the anomalocarids, artiopods, hyoliths, brachiopods, molluscs, and conodonts (early jawless vertebrates).                | ~489.5
